comments.commentBody: Oscar Robertson went to an all-black school in Indianapolis that won back to back state championships in 1955-56.  He was Mr. Indiana's Mr. Basketball in 1956.  It is often said only half jokingly that he ended segregated schools in basketball mad Indiana.

Yes, and the left-run Congress that has used the SS extra funds to fight poverty, drug wars, and wars in general can't find money to keep it's promises.  When you spend more money than you have, the nation can't retire.

As we've always been taught, Dr. PK - the objective in the 30s was to take care of as many of the old as possible, trying to decrease poverty on farms, especially. Whereas today, it seems the GOP'er objective is to take care of as few as possible as cheaply as humanly possible.

When talking to someone like JS, who spends at least 15 hours a week on morning camera TV, plus ever how much time on radio, red herrings and zombies can crop up ad hoc, anywhere anytime - that group counts on pulling something out of the air which isn't immediately provably wrong, since the details prove the lie, and by nature, details aren't at the fingertips.

It's more and more unbelievable each time we see some glib smiley faced winger who has all the answers to solve everything - in short little sound-bites acting as if nothing is complicated and there are no nuances to any problem - nothing's complicated as solutions pour from their lips.

And stop interfering in American Politics (separation of church and state, you know).

Of course, the church should express its opinion, no matter how misguided it might be. But, it should be funding NOM with millions of dollars.
The Catholic faith and its teaching on morals are primarily based in natural law and the guidance of the Holy Spirit.

No objection to the helping of others, although given the immense wealth of the church (largest landowner in the world), it could do more,

We object to all the things most of the other posters list.

And the church is obviously not one happy family. All the Catholics I know only obey some of the church's commandments, which you're obviously not allowed to do.
Of the12  apostles, only Peter was possibly married.

Most of the new Catholics are in Africa and combine Catholicism with their own religion.

If you gain 10 Catholics per parish (which I highly doubt) how many have you lost? 20?

If your church doesn't change, it's going to be much smaller and lose most of its influence.

If that's what you want, you're welcome to it.
Thank you.  You just hit the nail on the head.  If you don't agree with the Church's teachings, then leave.  Quit trying to force the Church to be remade in your image.

Wags, Hardly a day goes by here in WP, when someone, very often like yourself, doesn't somehow KAYAK me up!

I do hope someone puts a stop to these derring-do individuals who heartlessly "shoot the rapids" before these poor harmless CARROT eating creatures are placed on the endangered species list?

CHEERS, HOQ

1 Corinthians 6:19-20
19 Do you not know that your bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, who is in you, whom you have received from God? You are not your own; 20 you were bought at a price. Therefore honor God with your bodies.
Comparing Chavez to MLK amounts to defamation of Dr. King. Shame, shame. Putting JFK into such company definitely defines someone as a yahoo.
Indeed Chavez' death is tragic for many Venezuelans. I'm glad though, that it was the hand of God that took Chavez away from them and not the CIA.
The US citizens elect incompetent clowns and idiots, too, so I suppose it is just human nature to want to be fleeced.

President Hugo Chavez was a historic, charismatic and beloved leader in Venezuela. His election was popular and legitimate. Did everybody in Venezuela vote for him, was he perfect, did everybody agree with him and love him: No, but most Venezuelans’ did and they are now in great pain.
For Venezuelans’, President Chavez’s death is as tragic for them as was President John F. Kennedy’s or the Reverend Martin Luther King’s for Americans. Many Americans and foreign people of the world were not fond of JFK and MLK, and they disagreed and even hated them for many different reasons.
When JFK and MLK died the people of the world with any culture, class or education showed their respects to the American people who were in shock. The yahoos of that day showed their lack of culture, lack of education, lack of manners and childishness too with their glee.
During this time of the people’s and country’s grieving in Venezuela we should all show respect and dignity and American exceptionalism towards their grief now.
Those that make rude or mocking comments at this time are just showing their own ignorance, lack of culture, crudeness and disgusting immaturity. It is disheartening to see that so many Americans have become so crude, cruel and petty.
Venezuelans are as free to mourn as North Koreans, apparently. Perhaps some discredited NBA star is on his way south even now.

The photos of hysterical Venezuelans seem staged. It's not like he died in a plane crash...he had been sick for a couple of years and finally succumbed to cancer after a number of (presumably risky) surgeries and a silly photo op with his daughters.

Deb, I had to play "I Get Around" twice.

Drummers are always cool, but now I see again why it's good to play an instrument --- something to do with your hands! WHAT are those dance moves at 1:00 minute? Yesterday's hip....!

Think I'll go back for thirds.

Business does not have to be bad for "the people", look at Brazil, the economy has boomed and many lives have been improved...  And yes , he did something right just likeEva Peron in  Argentina, he threw some of his stolen money at them...look what the cocaine kingpins do, they build roads, schools etc and the surrounding society falls to ruin!  Venezuela does not need iran or North Korea, rather a world of open societies and new ideas...This guy was a snake oil merchant who jailed anyone in his way and bribed the poor for power and continuity.

And he provided millions of poor people with food and resources in his country, something economic libertarians can't stand.  Hey, what about Wall Streets billions in taxes not collected and loopholes the size of Milwaukee.  Some guys in Congress give Wall Street a pass, a genuflect, in fact.  Warped, indeed!  Not a fan of Chavez, but am willing to acknowledge the good things he did for the destitute and poor.

"Venezuelan President Chavez was once asked why the US elite wanted to kill him. Hugo: It’s the oil. And it’s the Koch Brothers – and it’s the ketchup."

How classic. In the progressive mind, the Koch brothers are everywhere, behind every door, under every bed. Even opposing things they actually support, like gay marriage, and taking positions on things they could care less about, like Venezuela.

And ketchup!!
Oh thank dog! I was waiting for that all-important Sean Penn statement. Now I can continue with my life.
Sean Penn immediately released a statement: http://hollywoodandswine.com/sean-penn-to-honor-late-friend-hugo-chavez-...

I visited Venezuela BEFORE Chavez took power and saw horrifying poverty.

On the way to Caracas from the airport, we passed right by unsteady hovels built tightly packed on what looked like landslide-prone hillsides. Indeed, when I mentioned this to someone at a company I was visiting, she said that her housekeeper would wake her children whenever it rains at night to bring them to stand at the door, so that they would not be crushed in the house if there were a landslide.

Having seen such poverty in spite of Venezuela's great oil wealth, I understood immediately why many were attracted to Chavez when he came onto the scene in spite of faults that may seem clear to us at a distance.

Why was it that we did not complain as loudly about great poverty in the face of Venezuela's oil wealth before he arrived?
Right, the very prosperous country that he inherited when he came to power, eh?

There are many native Venezuelans who are ardent Chavez supporters commenting here, but most of them seem to live here in the US.

Interesting.

I have to wonder if any of the Chavez defenders in this long line of commenters have ever been to Venezuela.  If they had, they would see horrifying poverty (even by Latin American standards) and an out of control crime rate, replete with police corruption and graft.  Despite the country's immense oil wealth, it his difficult to see how Chavez improved the lives of the poor.  Instead, he has left in shambles what could be a very prosperous country.

"Mr. Chávez, 58, changed Venezuela in fundamental ways, empowering and energizing millions of poor people who had felt marginalized and excluded. But his rule also widened society’s divisions."

This widened society's divisions? I think this reporter has it backwards. Both in terms of money and political power, the poor and marginalized are far closer to the rich than they were before Mr. Chavez was elected. In these terms, society's divisions have narrowed, not widened. Perhaps this is why Mr. Chavez has been reelected several times in what neutral observers reported as honest elections. Those who didn't support him tended to be the rich and powerful whose distance from the rest of the population has diminished. Perhaps they would prefer that the distance had widened.
People die of cancer in Sloan Kettering every day.

I am not in agreement with your "actual definition" of a monopoly? please cite. As I remember, from business law classes, monopolies are not illegal.
For a monopoly to be illegal it must have impact on the larger "market" that prevents competitors from entering the market by the "nature" of the way the company conducts business. If the "nature" of the monopoly unfairly prevents competitors from competing, then the monopoly is illegal, because it prevents or limits consumers from experiencing other choices.
As I remember it, the courts are looking to protect choice and access to the larger market ; Not individual commodities, products or services.
Correct me if I am wrong here.
Tom, I think John is having sport with his grey poupon, James.   Where are the other Apostles on this one?

Sigh. Yet another uninformed reference to the "mooching 47%-ers."

For the record, 47% of Americans pay no federal income tax. That does NOT mean that 47% of Americans pay NO taxes. It just means they have SO LITTLE LEFT after payroll, state, and local taxes the government lets them off the hook, and they pay no federal income tax. Some 60% of households in this category live on an income (yes, these people have jobs or they wouldn't be paying payroll taxes) of less than $20,000 a year. Try living on that, Mr. 1%.

C'mon, John, we know you're really a guy who takes tickets in the subway having a little fun pretending with us.

The real 1% folks wouldn't be caught dead typing blog posts on the NYT. They have people for that.

But you do pretty well at capturing the blase and bizarre self-entitlement of those rich loafers, and their belief that actual work is beneath them. I have to give you props for that.

It seems that the only way to stay ahead of the Democratic Party's tax hikes is to have stocks go to the moon.

All this class envy about investors making money at the expense of the less fortunate is so boring. So, "2008". If you want to get ahead, you must look forward, not backward.

So I say to the 47%, the takers, the moochers; the time of your reckoning is near.
Either pay your way or we'll pay to get you out of the way.

And to my fellow 1 per-centers can you please pass the Grey Poupon.
I saw a small, obscure item buried in the Times that this may have more to do with the renewal of certain Chinese contracts than all this other chatter.  Smoke screen for some more Chinese profit??
Said by a true non-investor.
